newsitem.title: INDIA: India's SBI cuts prime rate to 13.5 pct.
newsitem.headline: India's SBI cuts prime rate to 13.5 pct.

text.p: State Bank of India, the country's largest commercial bank, said in a statement on Saturday its prime lending rate will be cut to 13.5 percent from 14.0 percent, effective July 1.
The SBI cut followed the Reserve Bank of India's decision on Wednesday to reduce its key bank rate to 10 percent from 11.0.
The state-controlled SBI also announced a reduction in the rate payable on deposits over three years to 12.0 percent from 12.5.
P.K. Bhattacharjee, SBI deputy managing director and chief financial officer, said the maximum spread of rates offered to borrowers above the prime lending rate was unchanged at 3.75 percent.
The rate on deposits of over two years and up to three years was reduced to 11.5 percent from 12.0.
The one to two year deposit rate was reduced to 10.5 percent from 11.0.
The rate on deposits between 180 days and one year was cut to 8.0 percent from 9.0.
The rate on deposits between 46 and 179 days was reduced to 6.5 percent from 7.5, and 30 to 45 day deposit rates was cut to 6.0 percent from 7.0.

The rates for non-resident Indians was cut to 12.0 percent from 13.0 for deposits over three years, to 11.5 percent from 12.0 for deposits between one and three years and 8.0 percent from 9.0 for deposits between six months and one year.
The rate available to non residents' non repatriable funds was reduced to 13.5 percent from 14.0 for deposits between six months and three years.
The reduced rates on 180 days to one year deposits and for six month to one year deposits by non resident Indians are effective from June 26. The other rates are effective from July 1.
